                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     probably to avoid premature optimization.  getting a version 1 done quickly and then iterating works in so many fields besides hacking.
467                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          there is a lot of good advice i use constantly that has produced great benefits for me over the years.  here is probably the best:get enough sleep.get enough sunlight.maintain a positive attitude.know a little about a lot.do not pigeonhole people.anger is counterproductive.keep stress to a minimum.exercise regularly.eat healthy.persistence overcomes a lot.you can't control everything.people don't remember much.
468                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   if you are trying to decide between two things, a good trick is to flip a coin. assign one choice to heads and the other to tails. you'll find yourself subtly "hoping" for one choice over the other. decision made.
469                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             "if you have a hard time deciding whether to do one thing or the other, always choose the harder thing. that way, you rule out being lazy."this has always made me uncomfortable. there is no inherent value in doing hard things. the basic argument is that doing hard things prevents you from doing easy things only because they are easy. however, this strikes me as being very similar to the monty hall paradox. let's say you have a billion options to choose from. to expect that the hardest option would be your best bet would be absurd. so why should it work any better for choosing between two options?
470                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        this article says absolutely nothing about the value of a formal business education.it says something vaguely negative about the value of business textbooks, the crapiness of which is pretty well established and acknowledged by professors and students alike.  see here for a classic example:  http://www.textbookleague.org/103feyn.htm  this refers to highschool textbooks but applies equally well, if not more so, to college business texts.it's all about the professors.  business is one of those academic fields, like paul graham notes, where the best practitioners are not the educators.  while this is very true as a generalization, there are exceptions -- mainly:  non-practicing educators who happen to be excellent at imparting practical knowledge, and ex-practioners who were once tops in their field.  you will find these professors concentrated in top schools, and you will not find them teaching from these textbooks.  so there is actually quite a lot of value in a business education from a top school.  the well-worn cliche about the value of networking at these institutions applies as well -- and it's not just networking in the abstract, it's learning how to network with people who can get things done, and getting things done for people who expect big things out of you.  just like i'm sure it is in computer science, the value of the education is what you extract from it.\n
471                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   wow, what a useless blog post that was.a much better, less flame-worthy title would have been: "what is the value of reading a 101 level business textbook from 2005?"a formal, good, business education is invaluable, in combination with some domain-specific skill(i do think the pseudo-advertising in the book is appalling)it's not very useful to know about how "business works" without knowing and experiencing a real living value chain [whether it be retail, financial services, web software, or film making, etc].(disclosure, i have a b.s. in finance from the university of virginia...and an mfa in percussion performance from calarts...all we did at uva was read hbr and other intellectually stimulating material and then get grilled on it in full-class discussions...not to mention courses in c++ [viva the 1990's], statistics, and black-scholes ;-)

474                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                i think the problem here is textbooks, not the subject: in a java course i took, students were required to discuss the moral implications of writing software for judging people's credit (apparently, the problem was that creditworthiness correlates with race).but perhaps business courses are so content-free because so much of business is, too.

490                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                i agree 100% with the article.many applications are not designed at all to be useful, because in the last months the market didn't rewarded\njust useful applications, but a lot of fashionable ones.sometimes to build something of really useful is much harder than to build something like twitter, but it's like there is no longer a connection between how well a tool will solve a long time problem and how much buzz, users, money it will get.add to this the fact that web 2.0 users tend to be the same set of users using all the services, and trying a lot of new ones: it's ridicolous the number of people that are just happy to add a new website to the list of websites they already use everyday.instead to look for web apps solving problems many users are looking for problems that the just-released-web-app can solve. instead to focus on writing interesting articles for their blogs this users will spend all the day visiting analytics, feedburner, sending messages in twitter about new services, reading tons of rss, ...fortunately there is a parallel web 2.0 market of valuable things that save our time and make our life better. developers seeking for a real business in the last years should look at this.it is also very important to try to improve over the useful things already released. to make a better flickr or a better delicious or a better reddit can be ways more interesting than to invent something of totally useless just to be new and original.

                                                                                                                                                                                                     i look at dozens of reviews from other people and i get a good sense of the pros and cons of what i might buy. i can then gauge those perspectives against what is important to me. and i find that overall they are almost all correct -- in aggregate. \n

495                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               i like the note about privacy. i believe it -- we need to push for a transparent society. certain activities will always be easy to do anonymously, but certain capabilities are just founded on identity persistence. i'm curious if there could be a framework that has great persistence of preferences and identity, and maintains anonymity.another note: it's all just software. that makes it easier to acheive if you integrate systems. it also limits reach. you still need to move your ass from point a to b to c. most of the time, you'll need to pay attention while doing it -- automated driving isn't part of web 4.0.also, there is a ton of legwork involved in services. many services demand people behind them. it would be nice if humans were only needed to thing -- to have and share desires/preferences/thoughts. right now, only a minority of people have the luxury to do that full-time.
496                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       tbl has been touting the coming of a semantic web for quite some time now. i love hearing about example applications but frankly i don't know how much of it i can buy into.think back 10 years to the examples we were being given about "surfing the net" -- while we have some really cool apps and technology today, things didn't turn out quite as people imagined. technology always has this habit of building alot of hype around potential, but always failing to truly deliver. additionally the whole concept of the semantic web requires that everyone freely exchange their data -- a lovely idea but a bit too romantic if you ask me.my first startup began by squatting in w3c's office space, two doors down from tbl. really, i'd love nothing more than for it to work but the guys developing the specs for the sw are so out of touch that i wonder if they really have the ability to gain mass adoption.
497                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               the world godin presents is definitely scary for me. i value my feeling of privacy, but as he points out it is only an illusion. the need for this illusion of anonymity is strong in our society because people don't want to take responsibility for their actions, or are ashamed.\nthe kind of openness described by godin requires a new paradigm and therefore can only be currently adopted by few.

                                                                                                                                                         going back to school is not identical with giving up . some founder go back to school and keep working on the startup while there . however , those do so much worse than the people who work on the startup full-time that going back to school seems , in practice , not too far removed from a death sentence for a startup.off the top of my head , i 'd guess we 've had about 8 startup where the founder went back to school . it doe n't only happen with summer batch . founder from winter batch do it too.usually the reason is that the startup is n't doing very well . however , that judgement depends a lot on how determined the founder are . one reason we now shy away from funding people still in school is that they often unconsciously want the startup to fail , because the idea of dropping out frightens them.a lot of startup look bad after 3 month . someone who 's out of school and ha to make it work or get a job in a cubicle will say `` do n't worry , we 'll figure out how to make it successful . 15                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            his real point is that something can be `` simple and powerful . '' in order to sound edgy he subverts the meaning of complex into something that it doe n't mean ( powerful ) , and base his entire argument on this sleight of hand . ( leading to statement that , out of his twisted context , are totally bewildering like `` it capability are complex '' . ) his argument about simplicity and complexity not being mutually exclusive is a matter of definition , and thus he undermines others by foisting his definition into their mouth and then screaming bloody murder when he deduces that changing the premise of someone 's argument doe indeed damage it conclusion . among other thing i think his comparison of stats between mongrel and fogbugz is fundamentally broken . mongrel is among other thing free . beyond the intense need to brag about his project 's success i ca n't see any legitimate reason for making that particular comparison . ( beyond this point i rant about his usage of hangul for his example , feel free to skip rest of post . ) his comprehension of the korean writing system , which is one of his `` powerful '' point , seems superficial at best . hangul is a language that wa designed by a small group of advisor when the royalty realized most korean were illiterate ( not enough resource to spend learning chinese kanji ) . how the hell are we supposed to be surprised that something explicitly designed to be simple , in fact , turned out to be simple ? some extra point can be deducted for the fact that they stopped using hangul for several hundred year until it wa institutionalized by the strong nationalist movement post wwii and made the official writing system in an effort to establish a unique korean culture . additionally we can pause curiously while noting that the average korean still us 700-800 chinese kanji in daily life , and that academic paper still use the kanji for particularly esoteric or complex concept ( although this is increasingly discouraged a it is viewed a elitism ) . he crucifies joel and don for using limited example to justify a point ... and then use a single example to prove his , along with unsubstantiated claim about linguistic researcher . the japanese katakana alphabet can represent many word very well ... until you try to do one with an l in it , and then it fails utterly . using one contrived example would n't reveal that , and it the same reason i doubt his point about hangul . beyond technicality , it ignorant to conflate the creation of one small group of individual six hundred year ago with the cultural preference of modern korea . using something a an example never work out if you do n't actually know about it .

37                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             to get wider use of lfsps , it would be important for more people to learn that you can and it 's completely reasonable to interface several programming language . you need to be comfortable with both language to work on the interface , but i find it surprising we did n't practice this at school at all.to explicate what the article touch : perhaps you really have to use java because of platform or workforce requirement , but it doe n't mean you have to use 100 % java . more experienced developer can build some of the low-level class using c++ via jni . they can also set up beanshell or jython for user interface and test scripters .
38                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                i totally understand people 's complaint about c++ . however i am never sure if they are aware of some library that may concern : boost : :function allows you to easily interchange function pointer , memeber function pointer and function objects.boost : :lamda allows you to define transient function at the call site . this make the old stl way more useful . to be sure the syntax can be a bit funky ... boost : :bind pull all the fun of boost : :lamda and boost : :function together.with only the tiniest bit of discipline boost : :shared_ptr 's mean you never have to worry about memory management again . boost : :any and qvariants ( from the qt library ) help you manage dynamic typing . so an array of boost : :any 's can hold int 's , char 's , string 's and anytypeyouwant 's all at the same time . everything i 've mentioned is either in the standard or will be soon . really undergrad c++ is only the beginning . the stl and boost are almost a language unto themseleves . i never use raw array or naked pointer anymore and it 's made development way faster while maintaining performance.pg asked , why use a language where adaptor have to be built to get the functionality of lisp rather than lisp itself ( or something like that . ) i see his point but if the effort of getting lisp to work with c/c++ based code is greater than the pain of using an lfm , why not make the best of an lfm ? ha anyone had the same experience ? or am i putting the `` as '' in mass ?
39                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          for ( i = 0 ; i & # 60 ; n ; i++ ) odd example to use . it 's always annoying to re-type the same thing over and over . but i recently went through a mountain of my java code and replaced : for ( object obj : list ) withint size=list.size ( ) ; for ( int index=0 ; index & # 60 ; size ; index++ ) i 'm definitely very long suffering ! it took a few hour but what you get with abstraction is a loss of control over implementation . when you use the tighter loop , the compiler turn everything ( roughly ) into this : iterator it=list.iterator ( ) ; //which call new listitr ( ) ; for ( it.hasnext ( ) ) { object next=it.next ( ) ; the abstraction ha to do that because it doe n't know whether the list ( really , the java.util.collection ) is a linkedlist or an arraylist or a set . if your loop itself is in a tight loop , it is n't hard to call it million and million of time during program execution -- which make million and million of unnecessary allocation and method call . there is a loss of performance which , at the end of the day , is more important than how much you enjoy your job . of course , other language would allow you to specify an implementation for a given abstraction .

online and you can get them when you arrive at work.i think some simple comment like this could really help .

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 i for one am completely anal about version control . i work in engineering office and version control of , for instance detailed design drawing , is extremely important - most thing worth building with actual steel have quite a few zero after them and you never want to have a conversation half way through the build that start with `` i 'm using v3.4.3.5 which one are you using ? '' . most cad software for instance ha version control a the entry point , not at the end . when i did a stint in an office environment i wa appalled at their version control ( it 's on the cfo 's hard drive and he just re-saves it a a new version - not neccesarily date driven ... ) and wa in a meeting with their multi-million budget review when two vp 's discovered they were reporting actuals v budget from two different version ( not sure if one or both were wrong ... ) . what problem/value doe versionate give to customer ? imho an unbelievable amount - centralised storage ( even on your own server ) , a weblink that only ha the currently released best version , the ability to import/export - these are all very good thing . i really hope you guy do well . oh and btw , i love the pricing scheme .

                                          there seems to be this new crop of ridiculously overdesigned website recently . versionate , docstoc , iscrybe , etc . i 'm not sure how i feel about it.i wa reading viktor frankel 's holocaust memoir recently . he make the claim that people find meaning in their life through meeting people , going place , doing work , and through unavoidable suffering.i think he 's right . and sometimes i think that web designer would do well to add a little unavoidable suffering.some of these new website seem user centric to the point of being obsequious . it 's kind of like when a guy is following around a girl and constantly doing nice thing for her . you 'd think it would be cool , but it get kind of creepy after a while.the concept is solid and the technology is brilliant . it just make me a little uncomfortable for some reason./least useful criticism ever : - )

65                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   on the topic of community makeup , here are some interesting finding that come from yahoo 's social scientist ( using yahoo list a the dataset ) :1 ) small group have higher number of core users2 ) private and semi-public group have higher number of core user than public groups3 ) people in private group remain in the core for longer4 ) a user who is in the core of one group is more likely to become a member of the core when joining another group5 ) new member who eventually become part of the core are more likely to receive message from other user who have been long-time core users6 ) new member who eventually become light user are more likely to receive message from other light user , if they receive reply at all.this suggests some strategy for building a strong group of core user to transmit social norm . for example , having an idea of who the core user are in other similar community and making a special effort to reach out to them if they visit your site.unhappily i lost the original paper and all i have are my note , so i do n't know exactly how they defined the core user offhand .

                                      this is what we did in my previous start-up : we wrote up the process of all that we were doing , then researched a much a possible about what kind of patent already existed in our field , and rewrote what we had to avoid infringing on those . the research wa the hardest part , but now http : //www.google.com/patents should be a big help . then , we took what we had to a lawyer and asked him for advice . he ended up helping u file the prov . for le than $ 400 .

85                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   in all the startup i 've worked at , there actually wa one uber-hacker who worked 80 hour a week . there were also a lot of guy who spent 75 hour a week in meeting and farting around on the internet , and 5 hour doing useful work . i 've been both of those guy at different startup . the myth come from back in the day when there wa a lot of code to be written . certain project , like game , have ton of code . even the sharpest programmer can only type so fast , and even the fastest compiler can only compile so fast . the only way for project like that to come to fruition in any reasonable amount of time is for people to work long hours.the nature of software startup ha changed . with web apps , the code base is relatively small and simple . there usually is n't a compile cycle . what happens now , is you spend all your time on system administration issue . shit break , you need to respond to it immediately . i sort of miss the day where programming 70 hour a week wa an option . now i 'm lucky to get in 20 hour of programming in between the 100 hour backlog of system administration that need to get done .
86                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           there are some programmer who were just born to code . they can put in monster hour everyday a long a they believe that what they are doing is cool . i wa lucky to work with one such individual at a previous job . he wa just phenomenally productive and he wa working way more than 80 hr a week . he could write device driver in day and entire file system in week . if you are lucky you might get to observe someone like that . in some way writing code to people who are good at it is almost an exhilarating and enjoyable experience . it is easy to get into the flow and then you just loose track of time . programming is not really a bursty activity . if you are unable to find the flow and immerse yourself in your code for hour at a stretch find another career .

105    i am in almost the exact same situation , except with 2 year of hindsight . i joined a startup straight out of college a employee # 13 ( at the time , it had about 8 employee in the office at any given time ) . it wa profitable , i liked the people , and they were doing some pretty cool stuff.overall , i would do it over again but probably will not remain with them for much longer , if that make any sense . some observation : the language choice will grate on you after a while . i dunno what the background of poster saying `` be professional . suck it up . '' is , but i actually liked java coding when i started , and have since learned to hate it . if you 're going in with a strong aversion to java & # 38 ; c++ already , it 'll probably only get worse.flip side is that you do get better at these language after you work with them a while , a long a you keep an open mind . there are trick and tool in c++ to help you manage memory - you should n't be tracing pointer from new to delete . and java 's verbosity is n't a bad once you get used it and consider `` for ( int i = 0 ; i & # 60 ; array.length ; ++i ) .... '' to be a single map function that just ha a really long name . ; - ) one question to ask that 'll help you determine if the language will end up becoming a total drag : are they using it because the problem fit the language 's strength , or are they using it because they do n't know any better and are n't comfortable with multi-language solution ? every mainstream language is good for something . in my case , i wa perfectly happy a long a i wa writing ide plugins and server software in java , and then became very unhappy once i had to write a webapp . ( imnsho , java is irredeemably broken for webapps ; the only sane way to do them is to strip out all the javaee bullshit and program on bare servlets , but then you get something that 's nowhere near a nice a python/php/perl . ) there are plenty of thing beyond programming that you learn from working in a successful ( profitable ) startup . otoh , it 's not rocket science . basically , you can boil it all down to : 1 . ) make something people want , 2 . ) charge more for it than it cost you , and 3 . ) fix problem now rather than later . every failed startup i 've been involved with ha neglected at least one of these : every successful startup ha done all three.i dunno what you expect financially out of this , but be aware that founder get rich , late-stage employee get paid , and early-stage employee get screwed . at least in proportion to the amount of effort they put in . one startup i worked in went bust , taking my 0.1 % of stock option with it . one that i interviewed at offered me about 0.01 % of the company ; i did the math , and calculated that at their expected $ 40m exit , i would get a whole $ 4000 . i have no equity at my current employer . my cubemate wa an early employee at ccbn , which wa sold to thomson for about $ 40m . he got $ 3k or so . i have another friend who wa employee # 35 at stratus and later a vp ; she wa rich for a while when they ended up with a billion- $ market cap , but ended up poor again after the stock crashed . if you plan on being an early employee at a startup , you should do it for learning or for the experience rather than any perceived financial reward .
106                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               if you think you 'll be unhappy doing the actual work that you 'll be doing when you take the job , the job is n't worth it . there 's no difference between being employee # 9 or being employee # 99999 in that regard.also , if they 're successful enough with their current language , you will not change them . taking a job saying `` i know they use x , but i 'll talk them into using y instead , and then i 'll be happy ! '' is like entering a relationship saying `` i know she doe x that drive me nut , but i know if i pester her enough , she 'll stop it , and then i 'll be happy ! '' doe n't work that way .
107                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               i 've noticed there is a negative bias towards the `` enterprise '' language by many on this forum . not calling out gregwebs in particular , just speaking generally . i think much of the negativism stem from the hacker mentality that big company are evil and that breaking the rule is cool . therefore anything that big company do or use is automatically uncool.nothing wrong with this mindset , but i think it often go too far with some . java and c++ are not bad language . yes , most large software company use them but there are some reason why they might be a desirable choice . one is that these language work well in a collaborative work environment . there are many proven debugging tool , established qa practice , very good ides with integrated revision synchronization tool , etc . while these may not matter for the hacker or small group of hacker creating something cool , they are very important consideration for a growing software company who ha plan to scale.so with this understanding in mind i would n't automatically rule out a company based on the fact they code in c++/java . ask them why do and you might discover that there 's more there than what meet the eye .
108                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         if you are really good at c++ ( gork template metaprogramming , alexandrescu 's modern c++ design ) you will be a or more productive than most average people programming in ruby or python . instead of focusing on the language think about the kind of people you are working with . today you will find a lot of kool aid drinking kid coding in lightweight language and quoting from hacker and painter at every opportunity . that doe not mean they produce high quality software

the advantage of a superior language to the advantage of knowing what a successful startup look like .
110                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  sound like you have a fun opportunity lined up . i would personally try to broaden your message some . kid get told what they should do all the time . i would tell them that one of life 's true joy is to find something you love and to spend your life working on it . then you could segue into a discussion of how hacking ha been a personal source of meaning for you . talk about the point you mention above , and then bring it full circle by telling them that any road they walk down can be equally fulfilling if they find something they truly care for : life 's value derives from what we do , not what we have . hope your talk go well , and keep in mind there is probably a reason you are being asked to give a talk and not me . ; )
111                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         `` building thing is fun '' start with that point . in fact turn it around and say `` let 's have some fun .. and also happen to build thing '' the other point are too abstract for 7th grader . for example , 2 ) is strongly empirical , partly circular reasoning . 3 ) and 5 ) will only appeal to the academic type who anyway work towards scoring in exams.a demo would be great . tune into some part of kiddie pop culture ( some handheld game or myspace or whatever ) and demo how that can be built . no need for snazzy graphic , even a bare bone version will work . ( i 'd go for html , javascript . biggest reason is that it 's easily accessible everywhere , and come with a decent ui toolkit and turing complete language ) i 'm assuming you have been invited since you are a practising professional . it 's the job of the teacher to explain how thing will be ( point 2 to 5 ) . you ought to be that person in front of them for those few hours.walk the talk . show the enthu in your eye , voice . kid pick up such thing better than any word . every gesture in your body language will matter . unless you successfully come across a cool , 4 ) will be a waste.hope that help : )

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    i currently teach seventh grader in japan . many of my student are just starting to learn algebraic concept and seeing word problem , i would definitely recommend trying to get their interesting from thing they do know : video game . since you mention you are in the vfx industry i wonder if you might be planning a maya/mel presentation ? i think that would knock their sock off , since you can see the real time change to the running system without all the compiling , testing . personally a an attention grabber i would start out with some of your `` eye candy '' stuff . `` hi , i 'm _____ and my job is to make this [ kick as image ] happen '' one request i have is do n't talk a if this is something for those only naturally talented in math and logical thinking . teacher want them to see potential in themselves to improve , even if they are behind , if they start hitting the book now they can do something like programming.lay out in no uncertain term how one might progress if they are interested in the subject . when i wa that age , maybe a bit older , there were some field i wa interested in but it wa all just pie in the sky kind of stuff to me . stuff you learned in college . not connected with the drivel at junior high level.i second the call to not use the word `` hacker '' rms lost that battle to hollywood a long time ago . the kid will find the true meaning to it later . coder , programmer , technical director ( ? ) are some idea .

144
