245                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   i 'm reposting my argument from the blog comment : '' given the screenshot you posted , i would n't really buy into your conclusion because you never really adjusted your design to fit the varying width . i think i can agree that have a landing page take up 100 % of the available width is a bad thing , but it 's not because the user is spending time turning their head to read content ( that 's a pretty poor argument ) ; rather it 's because user like to see visual boundary -- where the content of the site begin and end . your widened version appear to do a poor job of managing the space and a a result look more amateur than the thinner , more condensed version . there are multiple problem that i can spot right away with your widescreen version -- for example , the user preferred width of a column of text is 3.5 '' , and the right-hand utility section of the header appears to be disconnected from the rest of the page . problem such a those , stemming from the design of the page ( independent of it width ) are probably more than enough to explain the difference in bounce rate . `` furthermore , are you arguing that the decision made by cnn , digg , cnet ( et al . ) to switch to a native 1024x768 design wa wrong ? i think the conservative argument you make in your post is quite backward -- online store owner would do better to expand their site design and provide an enhanced experience for customer . ''
246                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        the scope of the experiment is so narrow that i would n't draw any conclusion based on this , unless i wa making a cheaply-designed , seo-driven , diet-pill selling website . even then , the difference could be attributed to poor design ( irrespective of width ) .
247 meeting ton of smart people , and i 'm close to dozen of good school . anyway , good luck , and stay upwind .

256                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 http : //www.zonbu.com/plans/commitment.htm zonbu want to provide a fair service to consumer . there are no hidden charge : you will not find those obscure setup fee on your zonbu billing . in case that you are not satisfied with our service , you can keep the device and get a refund of your remaining subscription balance minus the prorated portion of your zonbu hardware rebate . let 's take an example : if you choose the 50 gb every two year billing plan , you initially pay $ 99 + 24 $ 14.95 = $ 457.80 . if you cancel the service after six month , you keep the device and we reimburse you : $ 119.10 = $ 14.95 18 - $ 150 . also , once your subscription terminates , you have read-only access to your data for three month , both from your zonbu device and from any other remote access pc . during that time you are welcome to move your data from the zonbu server to another storage solution of your choice .
257                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             `` green '' is such a sale pitch , without much substance . recycling some part is important . but carbon offset do n't actually offset much energy usage at all . in fact , in subsidizing other form of energy , people probably use more energy from them . even the benefit of a low-energy computer is very small when compared to the biggest consumer of power in the home : furnace , ac , water-heating , etc .. but i suppose the lesson is that you can leverage misconceptions.and do n't get me wrong -- i love tiny computer . an old macmini make a perfect medium pc . bittorrent download box need n't be large also . i hope they have a version without the subscription fee .

                                                                                                                                                              being an hourly consultant at the moment i me.having lost one large client at a most inopportune time , i can attest to the peril , but when you get the formula down you can make a decent living and still have time to live.but the real fun is 262                                                                                                                                                                                                                    people jumping into consulting also do n't realize the cost of : -self employment tax -business expense -vacation ( 3 week a year ) -holidays ( 1 week per year ) -sick time ( 1 week per year ) -errands ( a few time a week ) -bench time ( all of the time between project ) you run the number and $ 60/hr start to feel pretty freakin ' ugly . ( note : i wa a consultant and built a 20 person consulting biz ... and then sold it . i 'll never be an hourly consultant again , if i can swing it ) .

                                                                                                                                   how to survive : take the idea that to be successful you have to `` make something people want . '' and apply it to consulting . ( e.g . provide a service people want ) if you want to optimize your per-hour take ( since you are bound by your time if you work solo that is the only thing you can significantly maximize ) keep on top of your skill and move with the market .

and others , so that is a non-issue . people actually trust it.better template that allow for easy and beautiful sale pitch would be nice . some of the 1996 era junk make me want to run for the 285                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             how about automatically created anonymous user account and ability to later merge into a regular user account with username and password.an anonymous account would essentially identify a single browser and enable server side storage required for full application functionality . should the user later feel like the registration is worth the trouble after all , he could merge one or multiple anonymous account into a single regular account.one thing to think about in advance could be to prepare for merging data from multiple accounts.i think amazon shopping cart did something along these line ?
286                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          you can only offer a limited feature set if you lack true user account . photoflock.com for example relies purely on client persistence to manage the user 's upload history . it 's a simpler solution than requiring account -- there 's le friction for a user to begin interacting with your site ( ie no registration process ) -- but doing thing like tracking account and providing reliable usage stats is pretty difficult.additionally , your user will never be able to ( easily ) sych between computer and to be honest you 'll eventually add user account anyway . that 's not to say that you 'll implement a full username/password scheme , but you will need some sort of server-side persistence.that 's where i 'm at in my development right now , and i 'm looking at a happy middle ground where the user can have an account ( optionally ) to do thing like sync between computer but will vary rarely be asked for account information . my advice would be to sketch out a road map and assume that you will eventually add some sort of user account -- and then architect your site so that when you make that transition your user wo n't lose all of their data ( a will be the case for photoflock 's history data ) .

your site to do a bit of video editing . in this case , i guess the purpose of registration is to save user state , beyond sessions/cookies . therefore , you could simply have a 'save ' button , only asking for name/pw once it ha been clicked . this way it up to the user to decide when/if to register .

building . i would say yes if you require your user to save some sort of content online . giving them incentive to come back to your site . i always thought that user registration add friction to any app . i guess it all come down to how it 's implemented and how easy it is to get user from point a to b on your app. ( e.g . reddit 's way of user registration come mind ) although the implementation of openid should ease that restriction a bit . in short i personally like the idea of not having to register on your app . why do n't you try it ? see if user like the system . besides it 's their opinion that matter anyways . is seems like a novel way of approaching web apps these day . hope this help ....

290                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              this is by far not the only gotcha in facebook apping . the application setting form is a magical mess of spagetti logic . the first thing your learn is your ca n't even access the most useful application setting in the form unless you choose `` other user can install this application '' ... then magically the form explodes with all the option you really need to set ... wtf ? ... and then the about text for your app is entered in two different form . choosing developed by a company vs. developed by individual cause different kind of linkage on the app about page .... the most drunken delusional designer at microsoft could not design a worse form than this.another thing you learn on your own is facebook doe not tell you the end user 's id unless the user installed your application . their doc talk about the login process but are silent on explaining the difference between login vs. install which lead to this madness about `` infinite session '' . all it mean is if the user installs your application == infinite session . if user `` log into '' your application == 24 hour session . needle to say it is easier if user installed your application , again not mentioned in the docs.oh and another thing , facebook doe not save application data for you . saving user setting and data is totally your problem to solve . it 'd be nice if facebook had an api to stash just a little bit of data for each app user but no dice .... oh and finally try submitting your application to the product directory ... sorry ! your application need to have at least 5 user before it will be listed ! ! how doe an application that ha n't lanuched yet and is n't even listed get 5 user ? ? ? such are the mystery of facebook .

                                                                                                                                                                    i know a few of the major carrier offer this type of service for a monthly fee . i suppose you could look into that , however there 's a build in flaw to this model.if you use a carrier 's backup service for your address/contact list , you can only use that with phone from that particular service . for example , you could transfer information from one at & # 38 ; t wireless phone to another at & # 38 ; t phone , but you would n't be able to move data from a at & # 38 ; t phone to a nextel phone . i 've seen some third-party device out there that will help you move contact from one service to another , but i have n't seen backup service that will allows for this functionality without manual ( hardware or pc software ) intervention .

                                                                                                                                                       i would take the first job . many people without doe n't play out . i graduated with a c major , and many of my classmate who graduated with the same did not have a very strong grasp on `` algorithm , performance , or what make beautiful code '' . do n't let the lack of a formal c education distress you . the student who know the most are the one who are off doing their own project and working with each other to create thing , those who charge through the curriculum learn a lot , but do n't internalize the knowledge , and thus retain little of it .

engineering and can easily compare approach to common problem . there will always be plenty of `` b '' job around .

303                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     obviously there are benefit to both option . personally , i find myself in similar dilemma . i studied c , and the whole time my goal in life wa to be a programmer and work with computer . then you get into the industry and you realise you have achieved your goal , and find you need new goal . you realise the it world is so huge and there so much to do out there . there is much more to it than programming.theres probably no right answer . i would reassess my goal . where do you want to be in 10 year . 15 year ? imagine the path to this goal , and i 'm sure the right choice will present itself . it may be neither of those option . in fact , i would n't limit myself to only 2.do you want to be a programmer all your life ? ( sound pretty boring to me ) . this is an important question to ask yourself . what is going to be the best step to where you want to be later on ?

305                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          this depends entirely on the sort of code i 'm writing.if it 's throwaway code -- that is , stub function for use while i 'm writing and testing other code , and which i know i 'll replace before production use -- i can easily end up writing a thousand line of code a week , or even more.if i 'm writing good , solid code -- that is , code which i expect to write once and then use for the next 20 year without ever making more than cosmetic change to it -- i 'll generally write about a thousand line of code per month.if i 'm writing best-of-breed software -- that is , code which come with a proof of correctness and at least a very strong argument for being the optimal solution ( e.g. , code which computes a roots-of-unity table in linear time with o ( 1 ) maximum error , and will thus never be surpassed by more than a constant factor ) -- i 'll typically write 100-200 line of code and a 5-10 page paper in a month . of course , this last sort of code fall into the `` yes , i would trust this to operate a nuclear power plant '' category , which is a rather higher level than most application require .

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 it may be the best answer is to change the question . why do people measure loc ? because they 're trying to measure the productivity of programmer . why are they doing that ? largely to decide how to reward them . so that is the ultimate problem . but it go away if the programmer work in smaller group , in the form of startup , because then the market decides how to reward them.so odd a may seem , the answer to the question of how to measure loc is : startup !

project is `` when it 's done '' . the only truthful answer when developing anything new and interesting .
308                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     it 's not how many line of code you write , it 's how effectively you both turn out feature and leave the code base in a clean state . the folk i 've worked with who crank out lot of code tend to be the one who missed reuse opportunity and did't refactor , leaving a mess for the people who came along later to extend their work.measuring by line of code is silly unless you also have a way to measure code debt .

in a day . i 've had 3-4kloc day doing the combination of these two . it 's possible because the coding is easy , and you have tool to help you do it . also , are we counting thing like macro in this estimation ? i mean , a single line macro could yield hundred of line of code once through the compiler .

312 the other side of the same coin , they will be more likely to just click on an ad they do like than muck with some sort of rating system.people do n't always know what they like , just because one day they find something attractive doe n't mean a week later or even hour later they will like the same thing .
313 321                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               just yesterday i had a thought about the link between paul and lisp . i came to the conclusion that since paul wa a published author of lisp book at the time , and saw an opportunity to use it in production ( maybe to gain experience and write another book about it to share his finding with others ) but ended up learning about startup , dot coms , investor , and user a well , he instead wrote essay on paulgraham.com and used some of them in his hacker and painter book.i dare say his essay are about starting up in general , and there is no secret plan to convert user into using lisp . every week on ycombinator startup news , somebody asks about learning lisp to do a web app , when there are way more other thing to worry about than the language . use something you want to use every day , not just in theory because someone else did . i 'd learn an unknown language if i wa at a startup that used it every day , but otherwise , i would default to using a web framework that i have already used in the past.my conclusion is that if you 're creating a web application using a web framework in any language you find interesting at the moment , go for it . because that 's exactly what paul did . it just happened to be lisp that he wa an expert at , but it could have been any other exciting technology.whether paul would use lisp today or not on a new project is irrelevant a far a your plate is concerned . he could use lisp , but it would n't mean that there are n't other good alternative . and if he did use a language other than lisp , maybe it would be so because he would want to learn web framework since he would n't be writing lisp book any more , but lisp may still be something he would normally use more often.i think this is a great question .

345                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  there are a lot of concept and subtlety that underly a tos document . however , to get a decent one , all you have to do is pick a big relatively similar internet site , and copy theirs . replace their name with yours , and their jurisdictional information with yours ( e.g . state name ) . that 's the starting point . then look at the other big internet site , and copy anything you feel is applicable . then read it slowly . if you do n't understand anything , post it here and someone can probably help you understand what it is talking about.if you really want to understand what is going on , i suggest reading this book : http : //www.amazon.com/electronic-commerce-ronald-j-mann/dp/0 ... and the case and statute it reference . but this is really unnecessary to get something decent.i do n't recommend hiring a lawyer . they will either go through basically the same process a described above anyway and then charge you a lot for it . if you have a specific issue with your site , you might want to hire a lawyer to help you draft specific provision that deal with that issue . but seriously , do you have an issue that facebook/craigslist/ebay/microsoft/amazon/etc . do n't ?
346                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                my best advice is to write it in plain and simple english . a tos doe n't have to be written in legalese . for a good example ( that got an award for being so good ) , check out billmonk 's tos and privacy policy . they wrote it themselves with the help of a nolo book ( available at your local library ) if i remember correctly.if you really want to use legalese , just find a tos from a website similar to yours and adapt it to your specific need .

've nailed it : who 's got `` an issue that facebook/craigslist/ebay/microsoft/amazon/etc . do n't ? 348                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      interesting that the comment on here ( so far ) are the exact opposite of guy kawasaki 's sentiment : http : //blog.guykawasaki.com/2007/06/482413_for_lega.html '' you could do le legal work and do it cheaper , but if you ever want to raise venture capital much le go public or get acquired for more than scrap value , this is not the place to save a few thousand buck . if you 're negotiating an investment or a liquidity event , you want someone who worked at brobeck , baker & # 38 ; mckenzie , and wilson , sonsini , goodrich & # 38 ; rosati -- a opposed to your uncle the divorce lawyer from penny , wise , & # 38 ; pound foolish or myinstantincorporation4less.com -- not only for her expertise but to show opposing counsel that you 're not clueless . `` just some more information to think about ...

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           if i understand you correctly , you want people to be able to use your data for whatever they want except to compete with you . so why not just make everyone agree to some form of a non-compete with regard to the use of your data ? just leave it broadly defined with the right to terminate their license at any time if you feel they are violating the provision or spirit of your tos .
351                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             so what you 're trying to do is prevent wholesale copying from competitor ? the trick here is the agency doing the copying . you want to say that user can copy it , but that third party can't.my suggestion would be to be very clear that what you 're talking about is bulk copying by competitor , and prevent it by requiring user to initiate copy , rather than third party .

365                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    about 5 year back i had an idea for a free wireless system . i 'd go and offer place like starbucks and chapter free wireless for their customer . the hardware at their end would be a simple dsl/cable modem hooked up through a small form factor unix box with a wireless card in it and a fairly anal set of firewall rule to prevent deep abuse.the business model wa to be setting up in line ad replacement on website with a focus on local business . you 're sitting in the coffee shop and an ad come up for 10 % off your next purchase at the book store across the corner , or a two for one this day only at the diner down the street.i wa working at telus ( big canadian telecom ) at the time and they had just started cracking down on employee running side business that crossed over their product and service line . i would 've been fired and sued if i would 've started it up , too broke to do it alone , and did n't have a clue where to go for investor or the like . i 'm still tempted to do this , but free wireless ha spread so much it would be hard to penetrate the market and convince people my way wa the best way.i regret not having the ball to say that three month living expense wa good enough , let make a prototype and get a test going and pray i can find some business minded investor in time .

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       idea are overrated . execution matter far more . grandcentral is very similar to a company called thinklink which preceded it by about five year . facebook coopted connectu 's idea . the history of high technology is replete with similar example . yet grandcentral and facebook deserve their success . they were n't the most innovative in their respective space , but they executed best . that 's what count .

to manage these interaction . there 're three main driver for this:1 . ) the cost of bandwidth continues to plummet . youtube showed that it 's feasible to stream decent-quality video to million of user at once.2 . ) the cost of gas continues to skyrocket . a commuting becomes more expensive , more knowledge worker will look for an alternative to commuting . given current technology , it 's easier simply not to drive than to find more fuel-efficient way of driving.3 . ) certain company and project are showing that it 's feasible to work in geographically distributed team . 37signals ha about half of their staff in the chicago office . the icfp contest involves a very tricky task that 's usually performed by team of half a dozen people distributed all around the globe . a lot of volunteer organization and nonprofit website have large ( sometimes & # 62 ; 200 people ) team and no physical office .

                                                                                                                            this is possible using the s3 storage engine for mysql , which is currently in beta . your database life on s3 , your host live in ec2 xen vms.as i understand it , if your vm is powered off , you lose cached data your database will then start re-pulling from the storage engine.you can fetch the storage module from here : http : //fallenpegasus.com/code/mysql-awss3/relevant presentation : http : //fallenpegasus.com/code/mysql-awss3/presentations/computerworld article : http : //www.computerworld.com/action/article.do ? command=viewa .... have i done it ? no . it 's something i 'm investigating for a startup which may have a need for elastic scalability . my main concern : you 'd need a list of consistent speed between s3 and ec2 . any current user know what this is like ?

382                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       in case you missed it , check the comment in this link [ http : //www.25hoursaday.com/weblog/commentview.aspx ? guid=f8e6 ... ] , discussed here [ http : //news.ycombinator.com/item ? id=33093 ] .the suggestion is to constantly write db log from ec2 to s3 instead of nightly backup , so that in the event of a crash you 're only likely to lose minute worth of data . also note that you can restart instance with no loss of data . it only in failure that you would lose data .
383                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          ec2 and mysql ( or memcached for that matter ) do n't yet play well together . we were going to deploy a big database across several ec2 instance but the lack of static ip and internal routing quirk make configuration and automated failover extremely complex . sadly , the ability to deploy lot of instance ! = the ability to scale effectively , at least for mysql/memcached .

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               just buy a real vps server somewhere and avoid all the issue with data persistence and ec2 . use ec2 for heavy processing and use s3 for backup/storage/static file server.going down the path you described will be full of pain .

395                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  if you had to design an engineering school from the ground up where the input wa an 18 y/o w/ h math + science and the output wa a good engineer , it would look nothing like university do today . engineering is diced into it core component and those component are diced into their core component until you end up w/ a prof drawing line and dot on a blackboard that have no connection to the line and dot being drawn on all the other blackboard you saw that afternoon . all the while your goal is to predict what line and dot will appear on the test in a month . i do n't deny the need for a thorough and disciplined understanding of math and physic . but ... i did n't understand the need for calculus until i needed a way to go from pos/time to velocity/time . i did n't understand linear algebra until i needed to transform vertex in 3d graphic . personally i do n't understand a hammer unless i see the nail . engineering school is all about showing you everything there is to know about a tool except what to use it for . i think e-schools should be like obstacle course where you have project that require understanding of a concept in order to complete them . class about said concept are given a the need arises . most e-schools suck . just take a many project based class a possible ( c is decent for this ) and get a degree . university also have lot of grant that nobody know about where you can get money to build cool thing . maybe this is just me , but i do n't think i 'm alone . and it probably explains why i failed to hang my picture with a chainsaw .

                                                                      a few year back i wa talking to the electrical and computer engineering department head at university of toronto about pretty much the same topic . he 's very much an entrepreneur - started & # 38 ; sold his own business , know lot of people in the industry , etc.it 's not so much something to `` teach '' a a culture that need to be encouraged . sure , you can offer some business , accounting , economics ( entrepreneurship ? ) course to engineer , and to some extent u of t doe that . but the important thing is , after you graduate chance are you 'll do something similar to your friend . all your colleague are only talking about grad school or working on their resume and applying for job ? chance are that 's what you 'll do . been throwing around business idea with your friend since day 1 ? you might actually decide to start something.do n't know if there 's an easy solution ... good course and guest speaker help ... entrepreneurship/business club might help ... but if the culture doe n't exist , how do you kickstart it ?

399
