400                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 edward de bono , the so-called grandfather of creativity , describes this approach in his groundbreaking book `` serious creativity . '' basically you always want to generate idea separately , then expand on them in a group . the reason is that a group approach from the start will squash somewhat crazy concept before sufficient time ha been put into making them practical . a a result , the most creative idea are shot down before they are given a chance to be refined.instead , if you generate idea on your own you can spend more time on a half-baked concept in order to round out it flaw . then once it ready , other people can help provide different perspective on the idea without shooting it down outright . therefore i do n't see this article a simply advocating a single founder approach . however , co-founders should harden their new idea on their own before proposing them to each other for critique .
401                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 what pmarca is ignoring is that most people wo n't even try to come up with idea by themselves . it 's pretty tough to spend hour by yourself brainstorming on one topic . when you have someone ( even a manikin ) a resistance it can really draw out your best idea . nothing make me come up with a clever idea quicker than someone suggesting that there 's no solution to a problem . the real world difference between brainstorming a a group and a an individual might be the difference between some and zero . what these group of co-founders do together is more complicated than just sitting down and trying to think of idea . i suspect the most productive setup is a kind of together-alone-together sandwich . together you talk about some hard problem , probably getting nowhere . then , the next morning , one of you ha an idea in the shower about how to solve it . he run eagerly to to tell the others , and together they work out the kink . -- idea for startup
402                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                the article mistake more idea for better idea . the benefit of working in a good group is not that you get more idea , but that you take the idea that you get , prune the bad one and combine the good one to come up with the 'best ' idea . if 'mutual respect ' or 'fear of looking stupid ' get in the way of suggesting something while working in a group ( a it quite often doe ) then you need to work on overcoming that fear ( individually ) and improving your rapport ( a a group ) now if they could repeat the study after having predetermined some criterion to judge the 'best ' solution to a problem , my hunch is that they would find that a group with a good rapport ( not a bunch of stranger put together ) would come up with the better solution ( all other thing - e.g . familiarity with the problem set , problem solving skill etc being equal between group ) . but yeah , it 's just a hunch .
403                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       `` in 1958 ... psychologist let group of four people brainstorm about the practical benefit or difficulty that would arise if everyone had an extra thumb on each hand after next year. '' wait .. what ? the power of brainstorming is apparent when two people are thinking about something they will both use . if it 's directly useful to both of them then two head are about four time better than one , if not closer to ten time better .

quiet time to reflect/brainstorm before going to bed seems to generate the most high-quality idea , imo .

408                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     i apologize if someone ha already mentioned this , but it seems to me that what you 're proposing is to provide seed funding for marketing company . by marketing company , i mean company that place product quality second to the marketing apparatus.i have worked for several such company , and at one time i wa information coordinator for the american marketing association , so i 've been exposed to a lot of marketing 'genius ' . one thing i noticed time and time again in all these place is the prevalence of 'internal marketing ' . when stripped of trendy buzzword and platitude about 'empowerment ' , internal marketing is a de facto ideology which stipulates that marketing is the primary driving force in every organization . it place product quality , customer value , and strategy in a distant secondary position . the problem with marketing company is that their myopic focus produce reactionary organization - more ad hoc institution than enterprise . 'marketing company ' are sometimes profitable , but rarely maintain a commanding market position for long if they get there in the first place . contrast these with the real product company of our time : apple , google , craigslist , facebook , toyota . the real profit and value are being created by company who focus on actual product . some of these company have little marketing apparatus at all , at least in the sense you 're talking about . this reminds me of a silly aphorism : you rob a bank because that 's where the money is . providing seed funding to 'marketing genius ' is like robbing twenty hot dog stand and hoping that one of them forgot to deposit their earnings that week . it 's only a good plan if you ca n't figure out how to rob the bank .

funding i 'm sure thing could have been easier and i might have been able to be to market right about now .

415                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         `` how do you protect yourself from these people ? it ca n't be easy . i 'm a fairly skeptical person , and their trick worked on me well into my thirty . `` it 's much easier to never get in the habit of buying thing in the first place . i remember two particular childhood event that dramatically shaped my consumption habit : in the first , i wa 4 year old and in the toy section of spag 's ( a discount warehouse near worcester ) , and really wanted a new transformer toy . my mom said `` oh honey , we ca n't afford it . we can come back next month and get it . '' and then ran over to take care of my sister , who wa throwing a tantrum over not being able to have a my little pony doll . i realized i could be the `` good child '' by never asking for stuff . from then on , my parent and i had a tacit agreement : they would buy me anything i wanted , and in return i would n't want much . lesson learned : sibling rivalry can be a powerful motivator.for the second - my parent refused to let u watch any tv other than pb until they 'd sat u down and told u about advertisement . and when they did , the conversation wa basically : `` the commercial are just trying to sell you something . they want to control your behavior , so that you 'll go out and buy what they want . '' i wa 5 year old at the time and could n't bear the idea of anyone controlling my behavior . after all , it wa bad enough when my parent told me what to do . the idea that some nefarious marketing guy would reach through the tv and make me spend money wa just abhorrent . lesson learned : make marketer seem like parent , but with only the evil `` you have to do this ! '' part and not the comforting take-care-of-you parts.the end result of all this ? i 'm 26 year old and still using my high school allowance for spending money . essentially every penny i 've ever earned ha gone into the bank and stayed there .
416                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         i think we 're in a transitional moment in history , where stuff ha become close to free but we 're still locked into a mentality that value it . i do n't think it 'll be much longer before we come around to realizing it.funny that paul should mention kid . when my son wa born , i wa given a lot of plastic toy that make noise . i 've seen them on the shelf at toysrus , and they are remarkably cheap . thing is , my parent and their friend ( who are crossing 60 these day ) came of age at a time when a toy wa a rare and expensive treat . they were generally made in the u , and required a lot of capital and first world labor . a large room full of toy wa a sign of the very well to do . when they were kid , a new toy wa a truly wonderful gift , and so they continue to give them.and yet their house were relatively cheap relative to their income . for 20 and 30-ish people , the great financial challenge is housing , not plastic toy . so stuff is very cheap , but a place to put that stuff is prohibitively expensive . i have a feeling my 2 year old would really enjoy a toy workbench . the item itself is awfully cheap , and i could probably get one for $ 25 on craigslist , but the real estate it 's sitting on is worth about $ 2k . ( i live in one of the few remaining unfashionable block of san francisco for the low low price of about $ 650/sq ft- on nob or russian hill this workbench would probably cover closer to $ 10k worth of floorspace ) . so here 's another way to test a purchase . think about how much floor space the item would cover , and ask yourself if it 's worth the are * $ /sqft .
417                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           when i wa a kid growing up in the ussr , `` stuff '' wa really important to everyone because everything wa really hard to get . those who grew up in the west ca n't possibly understand how valuable even the most insignificant stuff seemed there . petty theft wa rampant . if you left a load of laundry unattended you could come back and find even your sock missing . the `` stuff '' mindset is very difficult for some people to break . over the first few year living in the u , my mother had accumulated more useless stuff than most people who 'd spent their whole life here . after 15 year in the u , she still worry about leaving her stuff in the laundromat.i 've been thinking about the subject a lot over the year and paul 's essay is spot-on . the more money i make , the more i dislike `` stuff '' . i hardly bought anything since i started my first job after college . in contrast i used to buy a fair amount of junk before . my room wa always cluttered and i hated being at home because i felt like the stuff drained all my energy.it 's true that stuff owns people and not the other way around . my neighbor in cambridge , ma keep a backyard ( more like a junkyard ) full of used construction material and equipment , including 3 dead truck . he spends every single evening trying to straighten it out , but end up just wheelbarrowing stuff from place to place without any noticeable progress . i , on the other hand , am now able to spend every evening working on my startup , and not having stuff make me feel great !
418                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                starting a startup ha led to big improvement for me in this area . back when i worked for other people i wa constantly buying stuff . oh , the rationalization i came up with for purchase of very dubious value . i felt that i had to have every piece of the puzzle , only i did n't realize that the puzzle can never be completed.now that i 've gone out on my own i do n't have the time or money to spend like this anymore . it 's such a change for the better.here are some stuff-reduction technique i use : book : i have one large ikea bookshelf . several of the shelf are reserved a a 'rotating collection ' - when the shelf get full , i make myself sell some book on amazon before i get new one . the collection can never exceed the capacity of the one decent-sized bookshelf.every august , i take an inventory of everything i own and how often i 'm using it . this includes book , clothes , office supply , everything . everything get divided into three category based on usage : heavily used , not used at all , and marginal . i keep everything in the 'heavily used ' category . i sell , give away , or throw away everything in the 'never used ' category . then , i make a list of everything in the 'marginal ' category and keep it until the next year . if any given item is still 'marginal ' the next year , i sell it.you 'd be surprised how effective this is . what 's especially amazing is the crazy stuff you can sell over the net - someone paid 50 buck for a t-shirt i had n't worn in 15 year . last year i made enough cash doing this to buy a new mac . the reduction in clutter is even better .
419 actually make it easier to not accumulate stuff , because you do n't feel a pressured by `` good deal '' .

430                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          during high school some people wrote draft of assignment and then made a `` good copy '' to hand in ( it wa high school , so busywork wa common , i guess ? ) a teacher warned u that this is not going to work in university.true enough , in university i quickly learned to get thing right the first time - because i wo n't have time for a second try . it 's a habit i 've kept after i graduated.i think the parallel to software is pretty obvious . it 's easy to say `` i 'll rewrite this later '' , but when later roll around , you have 3 other deadline to meet . throw-away code might still stay in the production code for 2 year . refactoring part of the code is good and necessary , but there are only so many resource you can dedicate to it.i guess if you 're seriously considering rewriting something from scratch , you 're already caught between a rock and a hard place . rewrite , and you miss an entire development cycle at least - time that could be spent enhancing or adding feature . stick with what you have , and you have to work with a codebase that make development a nightmare ( otherwise you would n't consider rewriting ) .better to avoid it if possible - do a bit of planning upfront , refactor when you can , have enough test that refactoring is safe.at my last job we rewrote a large part of the application - but it wa done piecemeal , over two year , and never halted development or delayed new feature . refactoring wa `` snuck in '' a part of deliverable whenever it wa possible and safe . it wa worth it because the new code performed up to 2 order of magnitude better , and wa much easier to work with - but we never would 've been able to do it if we simply decided to drop everything and announce that we 're rewriting the app from scratch .
431                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     in one ongoing series of consumer product , my several-hundred-thousand-line codebase lasted for well over 10 year . there wa no reason to mess with it . yes , i thought part were messy ... but there wa also great stuff in it that i 'm very happy survived intact.then decade later , on an entirely different product , in a different business ... we had to migrate our product to a new o platform , a well a needing to fulfill much wider requirement for our customer . the existing code just would n't allow this , even if it were stretched and stretched.so i rewrote most of the codebase.in some way i wa tortured knowing we had a functioning product that already handled thing i wa rewriting ( even though it wa on an obsolete platform ) . especially since the rewriting process take longer than zero.on the other hand , the new set of code turned out smaller , simpler , more reliable , much more flexible , and is now working well a a foundation our for business.both side of the argument make sense to me , i think it just depends on the situation .
432                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     writing `` one to throw away '' is an excellent idea . you 'll figure out the hard part of the problem and if it ha a chance of succeeding . this is what a startup should do post demo-day.throwing away something that 's been tuned to target customer is a mistake . this is what joel is talking about.most importantly , these are very , very different activities.except , of course , when time and money is ticking and they 're not . then you have to brave ( which is what you call it when it work ) or foolish ( which is what you call it when it doe n't ) .
433                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 i completely agree with joel . i 've done major refactoring work by making a series of minor alteration that clearly do n't change anything . this approach take a lot le time and doe n't introduce nearly a many bug . our svn repository is at revision 4995 , and that 's forked from a project that 's 4 year older . imagine how many of those commits have been bug fix , and you 'll see the big problem with rewriting .
434                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       reddit did , with good results.i think if you do n't have a good idea of what you 're doing when you start , you might need to write a throwaway version first , see what work and what doe n't , then write the real app . i suspect in many case , bottom-up design will reduce the need to rewrite by giving you more opportunity to refactor instead of throwing out the whole thing .

                                                                                                                     so i 'm the guy behind hit forge.it 's changed - that pr is obsolete ( thanks pg , specialist resource to help with seo and viral marketing . we provide free office space to our company , if they want them . we have a one-page no-hassle termsheet , where we buy something that look a lot like common stock . we do n't try to control the company . we help with future fundraising ( see my blog at http : //www.venturehacks.com ) . and we decide very quickly.pg pointed this out to me a a gap in the market for early stage web company , and he is absolutely right.see you all at y-combinator d-day .

440                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 sqlite is a great piece of code , but it 's intended for slightly different audience than mysql and other client-server db . i 'd use sqlite embedded in an application to store internal data , configuration , or a some domain specific file format . this way it is an alternative to xml or inventing your own file format . ( you get sql query for free ) . where you expect concurrent access and high load , a client-server still suit better . somebody correct me if i 'm wrong .

442                                                              not yc , but i know of quite a large web application ( in the order of a million user , but not that heavy traffic ) that make use of sqlite.i do n't think it 's the right tool for every job but in this case no data is shared between user . therefore partitioning is achieved by having an sqlite database per user.do n't underestimate the power of sqlite ( and to some extent other flat file database like bdb , tdb or cdb for fast lookup ) .

445                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         i 've been working with a programming language called erlang for about two year now , and their ram based database called mnesia almost force you into this 'sharding ' style.in erlang you also get the ability to have the same database on multiple computer or fragment the database into different server that hold only a certain piece.it certainly wa a trick to unlearn normalization technique i had been using for year , but once you get he hang of it the data really becomes or efficient .
446                                                                                  the sharding approach seems to be gaining popularity . it seems like a good datapoint in favor of the anti-database 447                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 there 's something familiar about this approach . it reminds me of jmp vs. ljmp command in processor instruction set that had partitioned memory set . or had a jmp command that wa distance limited ( often to +/- 32k ) .effectively , sharding take advantage of the locality of information . a soon a you need information outside of that locale , you need to make a more expensive request .

451 very well be that , for most people working 'inside the bubble ' , this one may , in retrospect , have ended very similarly to the last one . a lot of people essentially spent a bunch of year working for chump , in widely shared anticipation of rich that never materialized . at the same time , since not nearly a many outsider are betting their life saving on the 'bubblers ' , the economy wide impact of even the most devastating sector wipeout , wo n't be nearly a bad a dot bomb . in that respect , how you 'll come to view it will depend largely on where you stand . it could also be that what we are seeing is the leading edge of pg 's predicted trend for more young people to enter working life by doing a startup , rather than going to work for someone . this would probably in and of itself lead to an economic landscape looking a bit 'bubbly ' by historical standard . i guess only time will tell .

460                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          ok , i wa contracting in my previous life so i 've seen these issue pop up many time before . here 's few words.a ) is illegal . you have no ownership of any code or ip that you work on at the company that employ you . that 's what they 're paying you for , after all.b ) is also illegal . unless the company in question ha open sourced their code and allows anyone to use it under some kind of a bsd-like license , you have absolutely no right to use that code or ip.not only are both of these case illegal , they 're also highly unethical . also , if you 're forming a company around someone else 's ip , you 're gon na crash and burn.when i worked a a contractor , i would use my own library to save me some time but before i used them , i notified the management that i wa using them and told them that i own the code and that i give them full right to use it without any licensing fee and i also told them i would use them on my other contracting job . they always accepted these stipulation an i 've never had any problem . they loved the fact that i wa not wasting my time and their money re-implementing the wheel and that i wa solving their problem in record time . the key is to be open and put it all on the table before you start working.also , after i 'd finish working on a project and if i wa using my own computer , i 'd wipe my computer clean of all of their code . i would do that on the last day of my job and i always made sure that someone from the management wa there to witness it . sure , that might be going overboard but trust me ... it 's worth it . it show them that you care about these sort of thing and it also make sure that they wo n't have a strong case if they ever decide to sue you down the road because you end up inventing something amazing that 's in their marketspace or you end up working for competition .
461                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             if the code is a crystallisation of their business idea then using it again is equivalent to re-using their business idea and i think that is highly un-ethical . if you are talking about reusing some cs template and changing the color - meh . personally , i err on the side of caution and never take work with me from one company to another - often i can condense 6 month of learn-by-doing into a couple of week of do-over since it is the overall direction and knowing what is definitely wrong that save time . /note : i 'm a scientist not a programmer but i think the same situation apply

465                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      so i once watched this nutty 70 's film series on time management - 43 folder retro . it wa actually pretty good if you could get past the awful fashion . the host , a professor in horn-rimmed glass and a bowtie , had a piece of advice i found surprising at first . it put a different spin on doing hard thing and i 've found it very useful.he said if something is truly hard to do , put it off a long a possible . but if something is merely distasteful , do it a soon a possible.the rationale is that if something is truly hard to do , you can spend time thinking about it , researching it , gathering resource and asking others about it while doing other necessary thing . oftentimes , there will be a way to make the hard thing easier or even unnecessary.but if something is more distasteful than hard-to-do , you need to do it right away . it 's worse to put off distasteful thing than just get them over with.anyway , that bit of wisdom ha worked for me . in programming specifically , i also endorse david heinemeier hansson 's advice : `` if something is too hard it mean that you 're not cheating enough . ''

468                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            if you are trying to decide between two thing , a good trick is to flip a coin . assign one choice to head and the other to tail . you 'll find yourself subtly `` hoping '' for one choice over the other . decision made .
469                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             `` if you have a hard time deciding whether to do one thing or the other , always choose the harder thing . that way , you rule out being lazy . `` this ha always made me uncomfortable . there is no inherent value in doing hard thing . the basic argument is that doing hard thing prevents you from doing easy thing only because they are easy . however , this strike me a being very similar to the monty hall paradox . let 's say you have a billion option to choose from . to expect that the hardest option would be your best bet would be absurd . so why should it work any better for choosing between two option ?
470                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          this article say absolutely nothing about the value of a formal business education.it say something vaguely negative about the value of business textbook , the crapiness of which is pretty well established and acknowledged by professor and student alike . see here for a classic example : http : //www.textbookleague.org/103feyn.htm this refers to highschool textbook but applies equally well , if not more so , to college business texts.it 's all about the professor . business is one of those academic field , like paul graham note , where the best practitioner are not the educator . while this is very true a a generalization , there are exception -- mainly : non-practicing educator who happen to be excellent at imparting practical knowledge , and ex-practioners who were once top in their field . you will find these professor concentrated in top school , and you will not find them teaching from these textbook . so there is actually quite a lot of value in a business education from a top school . the well-worn cliche about the value of networking at these institution applies a well -- and it 's not just networking in the abstract , it 's learning how to network with people who can get thing done , and getting thing done for people who expect big thing out of you . just like i 'm sure it is in computer science , the value of the education is what you extract from it .

               wow , what a useless blog post that was.a much better , le flame-worthy title would have been : `` what is the value of reading a 101 level business textbook from 2005 ? `` a formal , business work '' without knowing and experiencing a real living value chain [ whether it be retail , financial service , web software , or film making , etc ] . ( disclosure , i have a b.s . in finance from the university of virginia ... and an mfa in percussion performance from calarts ... all we did at uva wa read hbr and other intellectually stimulating material and then get grilled on it in full-class discussion ... not to mention course in c++ [ viva the 1990 's ] , statistic , and black-scholes ; - )

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             i agree 100 % with the article.many application are not designed at all to be useful , because in the last month the market did n't rewarded just useful application , but a lot of fashionable ones.sometimes to build something of really useful is much harder than to build something like twitter , but it 's like there is no longer a connection between how well a tool will solve a long time problem and how much buzz , user , money it will get.add to this the fact that web 2.0 user tend to be the same set of user using all the service , and trying a lot of new one : it 's ridicolous the number of people that are just happy to add a new website to the list of website they already use everyday.instead to look for web apps solving problem many user are looking for problem that the just-released-web-app can solve . instead to focus on writing interesting article for their blog this user will spend all the day visiting analytics , feedburner , sending message in twitter about new service , reading ton of r , ... fortunately there is a parallel web 2.0 market of valuable thing that save our time and make our life better . developer seeking for a real business in the last year should look at this.it is also very important to try to improve over the useful thing already released . to make a better flickr or a better delicious or a better reddit can be way more interesting than to invent something of totally useless just to be new and original .

                                                        i understand his point , but i think he support it poorly . of course a product that ha 1 review is not likely to benefit greatly from that single review . but when i buy a product , or book a hotel , i look at dozen of review from other people and i get a good sense of the pro and con of what i might buy . i can then gauge those perspective against what is important to me . and i find that overall they are almost all correct -- in aggregate .

it seems like the author would find traditional , client-based application more useful than server-side web application . the whole point of the latter is to use everyone 's data to make software more          i like the note about privacy . i believe it -- we need to push for a transparent society . certain activity will always be easy to do anonymously , but certain capability are just founded on identity persistence . i 'm curious if there could be a framework that ha great persistence of preference and identity , and maintains anonymity.another note : it 's all just software . that make it easier to acheive if you integrate system . it also limit reach . you still need to move your as from point a to b to c. most of the time , you 'll need to pay attention while doing it -- automated driving is n't part of web 4.0.also , there is a ton of legwork involved in service . many service demand people behind them . it would be nice if human were only needed to thing -- to have and share desires/preferences/thoughts . right now , only a minority of people have the luxury to do that full-time .
496                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          tbl ha been touting the coming of a semantic web for quite some time now . i love hearing about example application but frankly i do n't know how much of it i can buy into.think back 10 year to the example we were being given about `` surfing the net '' -- while we have some really cool apps and technology today , thing did n't turn out quite a people imagined . technology always ha this habit of building alot of hype around potential , but always failing to truly deliver . additionally the whole concept of the semantic web requires that everyone freely exchange their data -- a lovely idea but a bit too romantic if you ask me.my first startup began by squatting in w3c 's office space , two door down from tbl . really , i 'd love nothing more than for it to work but the guy developing the spec for the sw are so out of touch that i wonder if they really have the ability to gain mass adoption .

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             the world godin present is definitely scary for me . i value my feeling of privacy , but a he point out it is only an illusion . the need for this illusion of anonymity is strong in our society because people do n't want to take responsibility for their action , or are ashamed . the kind of openness described by godin requires a new paradigm and therefore can only be currently adopted by few .
